results.title: Streetlife
results.creator_credit: Business Victoria: Dept of State Development and Image Link
results.brief_description: Four programs examine ways small communities have created employment. Program 1: Profiles the Beechworth Bakery as an example of a booming small business and tries to identify the factors which have made it successful. Program 2: Examines ecotourism in Kaikoura, New Zealand where the recognition of a natural feature has turned the town economy around. Program 3: Overviews Ouyen’s signage and streetscape projects which put the town on the tourist map. Program 4: Highlights Oamaru, New Zealand where the conservation of heritage buidings provided employment and attracted tourist dollars.

results.title: Stranger in his own country
results.brief_description: Shows the work of the Society’s Training Centre in preparing mentally handicapped young people to live and work as relatively independent adults, making the most of their abilities and living in the normal community.

results.title: Stranger's kiss
results.creator_credit: Matthew Chapman, Douglas Dilge and Kill Productions
results.brief_description: Hollywood, 1955, and independent film director Stanley (Peter Coyote) is eking out production day by day on a film financed by gangster Frank Silva, and starring Silva’s girlfriend, Carol (Victoria Tennant) as the leading lady, Betty. Stanley’s film is a love story about a boxer, a gangster, and a girl, and in a case of life imitating art, the leading actor (Blaine Novak) falls in love with Carol/Betty, unbeknownst that she already has a boyfriend who also happens to he a vicious gangster and the financer of the film. This film about a film is supposedly a fictionalised account on what went on behind the production of Kubrick’s “Killer’s kiss”, and has earned comparisons to a later production - Woody Allen’s “Bullets over Broadway” (1994). Cast also includes Richard Romanus and Dan Shor.

results.title: Story of a book
results.brief_description: This program follows author Holling C. Holling through the process of creating “Pagoo”, the story of a hermit crab. Relates the steps involved in writing a book: the birth of an idea, doing the research, writing and rewriting, illustrating and printing. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Storm of fire: World War II and the destruction of Dresden
results.brief_description: Presents a compelling documentary of the historical events that led to and included the destruction of Dresden, Germany, in February 1945. The events of the war between Germany and the Allies are followed from the early days of German victories to the eve of the bombing. The film shows the total devastation of Germany’s morale and strength. It is comprised of the actual sights and sounds of the events taken from archive footage and recordings. The culminating destruction is one of history’s terrible commentaries of the consequences and tragedy of total war.

results.title: Stop the red steer
results.brief_description: Shows the devastation of areas near Hobart in the February 1967 bushfires and the efforts of regular and volunteer firefighters to control them. Demonstrates methods generally recommended for preventing and dealing with bushfires.

results.title: Still Life
results.brief_description: This film starts out appearing to be an art documentary about a Scottish painter Lawrence Angus Mc Coney. It uses artwork, animation and photographic effects to give a vivid sense of the artist’s life. ‘Still Life’ is a humorous send up of art criticism but it also sets out to express what it feels like to be an artist. Narrated by Gary Bond.

results.title: Step right up!
results.creator_credit: Mike Lloyd Ross, Ray Jewell and Film Communications
results.brief_description: Illustrates the possible hazards and improper procedures when using ladders. Shows the proper use of stepladders, straight ladders, and extension ladders. Also focuses on inspection, maintenance, carrying, ladder stances, erecting and securing, climbing and descending. Camera: Peter Good.
